title: Kyle Rittenhouse Shooting Trial to Focus on Reasonableness, Self-Defense
sub_head: Jury selection to begin Monday over killings of two protesters and injury of a third in Kenosha, Wis., last year; state law on self-defense could hinder prosecution, lawyers say
body:
Prosecutors in the trial of Kyle Rittenhouse, the teenager who killed two people and injured a third during unrest in Kenosha, Wis., last year, will have to overcome a longstanding law in Wisconsin that makes it more difficult than in many other states to convict someone who claims self-defense.
Jury selection is set to begin Monday in Mr. Rittenhouseâ€™s trial on charges including first-degree intentional homicide, first-degree reckless homicide and attempted first-degree intentional homicide. Mr. Rittenhouse, now 18, has pleaded not guilty and is free on $2 million bail.
